The key issue we discussed today with Prime Minister of Japan Fumio Kishida is security. We agreed to continue the dialogue on expanding security cooperation. We talked about further sanction pressure on Russia, how to restore justice violated by Russian aggression, and our cooperation in the framework of Japan's G7 Presidency. We also discussed Japan's involvement in Ukraine's reconstruction. 
As a result of our talks today, we have signed a Joint Statement on Special Global Partnership between Ukraine and Japan. This document reflects both our values, which we defend together, and our aspirations, which are yet to be realized.
Thank you for the negotiations and for significantly supporting Ukraine.

On the night of 6 June, the russians blew up the dam of the Kakhovka hydroelectric power station (HPP), perpetrating one of the worst terrorist attacks of this war. This terrorist attack is an ecological weapon of mass destruction.
1.995 people were evacuated from the flooded areas, including 103 children. 334 people were rescued, including 15 children. 20 settlements and 2,629 houses on the right bank of the Dnipro River were flooded.
The consequences are impressive. About 55 thousand hectares of forest were flooded. If there is still hope for the preservation of plants in the forest, the animals are indeed doomed to die. These include deer, roe deer and wild boar. Lizards, snakes, hares and hedgehogs have no chance to survive.
In addition, the destruction of the Kakhovka HPP has caused at least 150 tonnes of machine oil to enter the Dnipro. The deposition of oil on plants leads to irreversible consequences for the process of photosynthesis.
The undermining of the dam is a real ecocide! The terrorist state must be stopped!
